case_name: Nand Kumar, Brij Kishore alias Kalua, Lakhan and Murari v. State

facts.text: Eight boys from Dholpur City went to the temple of Mangal Bharti for a picnic on June 4, 1960

anchor.surface_text: On June 4, 1960 eight boys  1  Munna son of Manohar Lal  2  Ram Prakash son of Ram Baboo  3  Laxmi son of Vidhya Ram  4  Pooran son of Gulab Chand  5  Kedar son of Ram Kumar  6  Mohan son of Banke Lal  7  Suresh son of Chandra Shekhar and  8  Jagdish son of Mitthan Lal, all of Dholpur City went to the temple of Mangal Bharti for a Picnic.

facts.text: None of the eight boys returned home on June 4, 1960

anchor.surface_text: None of them returned home.

facts.text: On the morning of June 6, 1960, all eight boys were found dead near a well in Gundarai forest

anchor.surface_text: On the morning of June 6, all these boys were found dead near a well in Gundarai forest.

facts.text: Each of the eight boys' bodies bore numerous injuries which caused their deaths according to post mortem doctor

anchor.surface_text: Each of the bodies bore numerous injuries, which according to the evidence of doctor, who held the post mortem examination, caused the deaths.

facts.text: Seven of the boys' bodies were found naked, only Munna had clothes on; hands tied behind with trouser ribbons, mouths gagged

anchor.surface_text: Seven of the bodies were found naked only the dead body of Munna had clothes on. The hands of each were tied from behind with ribbons of their trousers and their mouths were found gagged.

facts.text: Watches, rings, buttons and currency notes of some boys had disappeared

anchor.surface_text: Watches and rings, buttons and currency numberes, which some of these boys had with them had disappeared.

facts.text: Four appellants Nand Kumar, Brij Kishore alias Kalua, Lakhan and Murari along with Jagdish convicted for murder of eight boys under s.302 IPC and sentenced to death by additional Sessions Judge

anchor.surface_text: The four appellants, viz., Nand Kumar, Brij Kishore, alias Kalua, Lakhan and Murari along with one Jagdish were all companyvicted for the murder of these eight boys under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code and were all sentenced to death.

facts.text: All five convicted under s.377 and s.395 IPC by additional Sessions Judge

anchor.surface_text: All of them were also companyvicted by the additional Sessions Judge under a. 377 of the Indian penal Code and s. 395, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court confirmed conviction under s.302 for four appellants, confirmed death for Nand Kumar, Kalua, Lakhan, reduced Murari to life imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction of these four appellants under s. 302 was companyfirmed by the High- Court of Rajasthan and the sentences of. death passed on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan were also companyfirmed. The High Court reduced the sentence on Murari to one of imprisonment for life.

facts.text: High Court confirmed convictions under s.395 IPC for all appellants

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction of all the appellants under s. 395 of the Indian Penal Code and the sentences passed thereunder were also companyfirmed.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave granted by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The pre- sent appeal is by special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Puran of Dholpur saw the eight boys with Nand Kumar, Kalua, Jagdish and Murari at Mangal Bharti on June 4, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Information was received from Puran, also of Dholpur City, who had also gone to the Mangal Bharti on that day that he had seen the eight boys and also Nand Kumar, Kalua, Jagdish .and Murari together at the Mangal Bharti.

facts.text: Shiv Narain, brother of Munna, lodged information at Kotwali police Dholpur on June 5, 1960 at 6 a.m. about disappearance of boys, suspecting Panna dacoits gang

anchor.surface_text: On the following morning, i.e., the 5th June, 1960 at 6 a.m., Shiv Narain, the brother of Munna lodged information with the Kotwali police Dholpur about the disappearance of these boys. He added his suspicion that these boys might have fallen into the hands of dacoits belonging to the Panna dacoits gang and kidnaped by them.

facts.text: Circle Inspector Bhanwar Singh contacted the five appellants on June 5, 1960 at about 10 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day at about 10 p.m. Bhanwar Singh, the Circle Inspector of Dholpur succeeded in companytacting these appellants.

facts.text: All five made statements recorded giving information about articles taken from boys

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately all the five made statements which were recorded,. giving information about their having kept the articles taken from some of the boys.

facts.text: On June 6, 1960 at 4 a.m., Nand Kumar led police to cycles, dead bodies in Gundarai forest, and knife Ex-18 from bush

anchor.surface_text: At about 4 a.m. on June 6, 1960, the Circle Inspector accompanied by the Deputy Superintendent of Police left for Gundarai forest in a police jeep a long with the appellant Nand Kumar and some other persons. Nand Kumar led the police to the top of a small bill and pointed out the five cycles of Munna and his companypanions lying at one spot and the dead bodies of the eight boys lying at different places in the vicinity of the hill in the jungle. He also took out a knife, Ex- 18, from a bush near one of the dead bodies.

facts.text: Nand Kumar produced Agfa camera, wrist watch from Munna, and blood-stained clothes from his house

anchor.surface_text: Then Nand Kumar went to his house with the police and there pointed out a camera and a wrist watch which had fallen to his share. He also brought out certain blood-stained clothes.

facts.text: Murari produced gold ring with R.P. Gupta, wrist watch of R.P. Gupta, bloodstained clothes, gold buttons and cash from his house

anchor.surface_text: After this. the appellant Murari was taken by the police to his house and he brought out a gold ring with the name of R.P. Gupta inscribed in enamel., a wrist watch belonging to R. P. Gupta deceased and some bloodstained clothes. The police then took Murari to his house where Murari brought out some gold buttons and currency numberes.

facts.text: Kalua produced wrist watch and ring inscribed S.K. Gupta and blood stained clothes from his house

anchor.surface_text: Then Kalua took the police to his house and brought out a wrist. watch and a ring inscri- bed with the name of S. K. Gupta and also some blood stained clothes.

facts.text: Lakhan produced gold ring R.P. Gupta and wrist watch, blood-stained banian and underwear from his room

anchor.surface_text: the recovery from his room of part of the booty taken from the boys, viz., a gold ring bearing the inscription R. P. Gupta, and a wrist watch  3  the recovery of a blood-stained banian and underwear from his room and  4  the fact that these were produced by Lakhan himself after he had made a statement that he kept these things in his house.

facts.text: Nand Kumar, Murari and Kalua made confessions before Sub-Divisional Magistrate on June 14, 15, 16 1960 respectively

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution three of these appellants, viz., Nand Kumar.Murari and Kalua made companyfessions before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate which were recorded by the Magistrate Nand Kumar on the 14th June, Kalua on the 15th June and Murari on the 16th June.

facts.text: Lakhan's statement recorded by Magistrate on June 15, 1960

anchor.surface_text: A statement of Lakhan was also recorded by the Magistrate on the 15th June, 1960.

facts.text: All accused pleaded not guilty, denied making statements before Magistrate and denied recovery of articles from houses

anchor.surface_text: All the accused pleaded number guilty. They denied that they had made any statement at all before the Magistrate and also denied the recovery of any articles from their houses.

facts.text: Supreme Court held confessions of Nand Kumar, Kalua, Murari voluntary and admissible, sufficiently corroborated

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the companyfessions of all these three accused were voluntary and rightly admitted into evidence. ... Applying this test to the three retracted companyfessions before us, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in its companyclusion that each of these companyfessions has been so well companyroborated- by independent evidence

facts.text: Recoveries from Nand Kumar's house matched his confession: Munna's Agfa camera, wrist watch, bloodstained clothes with human blood

anchor.surface_text: it has further been proved by reliable and independent evidence that Munnas Agfa camera and the wrist watch belonging to him which he had taken with him that day to Mangal Bharti were recovered from Nand Kumars house and that it was actually he who produced these himself from behind the floor carpet on the Tand of his house and that he also produced some clothes lying behind the floor carpet, viz , a white banian and a langot and a white shirt smeared with blood. There is satisfactory evidence that the blood on these articles was human blood.
The pre- sent appeal is by special leave granted by this Court.

The four appellants, viz., Nand Kumar, Brij Kishore, alias Kalua, Lakhan and Murari along with one Jagdish were all convicted for the murder of these eight boys under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code and were all sentenced to death.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to convict appellants for murder of eight boys based on corroborated confessions and recoveries.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Penal Code and were all sentenced to death. All of them were also companyvicted by the additional Sessions Judge under a. 377 of the Indian penal Code

anchor.surface_text: All of them were also convicted by the additional Sessions Judge under s. 377 of the Indian penal Code and s. 395, Indian Penal Code.
All of them were also convicted by the additional Sessions Judge under s. 377 of the Indian penal Code and s. 395, Indian Penal Code.

concepts.interpretation: Convictions confirmed; evidence from murder charge provides sufficient basis.

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of these four appellants under s. 302 was confirmed by the High- Court of Rajasthan and the sentences of. death passed on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan were also confirmed. The High Court reduced the sentence on Murari to one of imprisonment for life.

concepts.interpretation: High Court confirmed convictions and death sentences for three, life for one.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: uced the sentence on Murari to one of imprisonment for life. The companyviction of all the appellants under s. 395 of the Indian Penal Code and the se

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of all the appellants under s. 395 of the Indian Penal Code and the sentences passed thereunder were also confirmed.

We are satisfied that the confessions of all these three accused were voluntary and rightly admitted into evidence. ... Applying this test to the three retracted confessions before us, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in its conclusion that each of these confessions has been so well corroborated- by independent evidence

concepts.interpretation: Unsafe to convict solely on retracted confession without corroboration of material particulars by independent, reliable, non-tainted evidence integrally connected to accused's participation; applied and found sufficient here.

Murari convicted on basis of role in common intention (guarding boys while others killed).

issues.text: Whether Nand Kumar made a confessional statement before the Magistrate or was the record of his confessional statement fabricated in his absence?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of Nand Kumar an additional plea was pressed that he made no confessional statement at all before the Magistrate and the document which is produced as record of his confessional statement was written up in his absence on papers on which Nand Kumar has been made to put his signature.

issues.text: Whether the confessions of Nand Kumar, Kalua and Murari were voluntary and admissible in evidence?

anchor.surface_text: As regards each of these confessions, the learned Counsel has urged, as already, indicated, that it was not voluntary. Three grounds were urged in support of the contention.

issues.text: Whether there was sufficient corroboration of the retracted confessions of Nand Kumar, Kalua and Murari to establish their truth and sustain convictions under Section 302 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: Courts ordinarily consider it unsafe to convict any accused person on the basis of his retracted confession except where the truth of such confession is established by corroboration in material particular by independent evidence., what is sufficient corroboration for this purpose has to be decided in each case on its own facts and circumstances.

issues.text: Whether Lakhan participated in the murder of the eight boys under Section 302 IPC based on circumstantial evidence and co-accused confessions?
Whether the convictions under Section 395 IPC were sustainable based on the evidence?
Whether the death sentences on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan, and life imprisonment on Murari under Section 302 IPC were appropriate?

arguments.claim: Nand Kumar rightly convicted under s.302 IPC based on corroborated confession

anchor.surface_text: These facts and circumstances provide overwhelming corroboration of Nand Kumars confession that he was one of the three persons who inflicted the injuries on the 8 boys which caused their deaths. He has therefore, been rightly convicted under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Recoveries from Kalua corroborate his confession; rightly convicted under s.302

anchor.surface_text: These facts and circumstances provide sufficient corroboration of Kaluas confession. He has, therefore, been rightly convicted under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Murari rightly convicted under s.302 based on corroborated confession of guarding while others killed in common intention
Circumstances prove Lakhan's participation in murder under common intention; conviction under s.302 justified

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence overwhelming; unnecessary to speculate on motive

arguments.claim: Evidence sufficient for convictions under s.395 IPC
Death sentences for Nand Kumar, Kalua, Lakhan appropriate; no interference with life for Murari

holdings.text: The record of Nand Kumar's confessional statement is genuine and contains what he stated before the Magistrate; no fabrication.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that there is absolutely no reason to doubt the testimony of the Magistrate on this point and there can be no possible doubt whatsoever that the record Ex-P-62 contains what was stated by the accused Nand Kumar before the Magistrate on June 14, 1960.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of alteration in jail register beyond speculation; Magistrate's testimony reliable; accused present during recording.

holdings.text: Confessions of Nand Kumar, Kalua and Murari were voluntary and rightly admitted into evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the confessions of all these three accused were voluntary and rightly admitted into evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected claims of involuntariness due to delay (no police gain, natural to hurry), Paras Singh visit (for other case, no inducement), solitary confinement (for safety, common practice).

holdings.text: Retracted confessions require corroboration in material particulars by independent evidence integrally connected to accused's participation; applied here with sufficient corroboration establishing truth.

anchor.surface_text: It may, however, be generally stated that where the prosecution by the production of reliable evidence which is independent of the confession and which is also not tainted evidence like the evidence of an accomplice or the evidence of a co accused, establishes the truth of certain parts of the account given in the confession and these parts are so integrally connected with other parts of the accuseds confession, that a prudent judge of facts would think it reasonable to believe, in view of the established truth of these parts, that what the accused has stated in the confession as regards his own participation in the crime is also true, that is sufficient corroboration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Articulated and applied standard from precedents: independent corroboration of integral parts relating to participation; recoveries, discoveries under s.27, presence proved independently.

holdings.text: Nand Kumar rightly convicted under s.302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: These facts and circumstances provide overwhelming corroboration of Nand Kumars confession that he was one of the three persons who inflicted the injuries on the 8 boys which caused their deaths. He has therefore, been rightly convicted under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confession corroborated by independent evidence of recoveries (camera, watch, bloodstained clothes with human blood), discovery of bodies and knife under s.27.

holdings.text: Kalua rightly convicted under s.302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: These facts and circumstances provide sufficient corroboration of Kaluas confession. He has, therefore, been rightly convicted under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confession corroborated by recoveries (watch, ring of Laxmi/S.K. Gupta, bloodstained clothes with human blood), presence at scene.

holdings.text: Murari rightly convicted under s.302 IPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Confession corroborated by recoveries (buttons, cash under s.27), knife identification, presence; role in common intention to murder.

holdings.text: Lakhan rightly convicted under s.302 IPC based on circumstantial evidence and co-accused confessions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances (presence, recoveries of ring/watch/booty/bloodstained clothes under s.27) plus corroborated co-accused confessions prove participation in killings under common intention.
Murder evidence (robbery, presence, recoveries) amply supports dacoity convictions.

holdings.text: Death sentences for Nand Kumar, Kalua, Lakhan appropriate; no interference with life imprisonment for Murari.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Brutality of murders (eight boys) warrants death for active killers; defer to High Court discretion on Murari.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences of death passed on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan are the only possible sentences. The High Court has thought fit to treat Murari more leniently and sentenced him only to imprisonment for life. We cannot interfere with that sentence, even though it appears to us that this leniency was

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions of the appellants under Sections 302 and 395 IPC upheld. Death sentences for Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan confirmed as the only possible sentences. Life imprisonment sentence for Murari upheld without interference.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that there is absolutely no reason to doubt the testimony of the Magistrate on this point and there can be no possible doubt whatsoever that the record Ex-P-62 contains what was stated by the accused Nand Kumar before the Magistrate on June 14, 1960.

The sentences of death passed on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan are the only possible sentences. The High Court has thought fit to treat Murari more leniently and sentenced him only to imprisonment for life. We cannot interfere with that sentence, even though it appears to us that this leniency was

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the confessions of all these three accused were voluntary and rightly admitted into evidence.

The sentences of death passed on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan are the only possible sentences. The High Court has thought fit to treat Murari more leniently and sentenced him only to imprisonment for life. We cannot interfere with that sentence, even though it appears to us that this leniency was

anchor.surface_text: It may, however, be generally stated that where the prosecution by the production of reliable evidence which is independent of the confession and which is also not tainted evidence like the evidence of an accomplice or the evidence of a co accused, establishes the truth of certain parts of the account given in the confession and these parts are so integrally connected with other parts of the accuseds confession, that a prudent judge of facts would think it reasonable to believe, in view of the established truth of these parts, that what the accused has stated in the confession as regards his own participation in the crime is also true, that is sufficient corroboration.

The sentences of death passed on Nand Kumar, Kalua and Lakhan are the only possible sentences. The High Court has thought fit to treat Murari more leniently and sentenced him only to imprisonment for life. We cannot interfere with that sentence, even though it appears to us that this leniency was

anchor.surface_text: These facts and circumstances provide overwhelming corroboration of Nand Kumars confession that he was one of the three persons who inflicted the injuries on the 8 boys which caused their deaths. He has therefore, been rightly convicted under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code.
